articles.headline: Battle Starts Over British Bank Rules
articles.snippet: A proposal from a British commission is expected to suggest separating the trading and deposit-taking functions at the country’s banks.
articles.abstract: A proposal from a British commission is expected to suggest separating the trading and deposit-taking functions at the country’s banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Wall Street banks fight to fend off further regulation, the battle in Britain over how best to manage financial institutions considered too big to fail is just beginning.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Eric Dash

articles.headline: How Secrecy Undermines Audit Reform
articles.snippet: Disciplinary actions against audit firms can remain secret for years, so investors have no way of identifying companies that may be using inappropriate accounting practices.
articles.abstract: Disciplinary actions against audit firms can remain secret for years, so investors have no way of identifying companies that may be using inappropriate accounting practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the auditing industry, the financial crisis was really not that bad.

articles.headline: Stuff Piled in the Aisle? It’s There to Get You to Spend More
articles.snippet: In the face of evidence that jam-packed stores encourage sales, retailers are redesigning their space to stuff in more displays.
articles.abstract: In the face of evidence that jam-packed stores encourage sales, retailers are redesigning their space to stuff in more displays.

articles.headline: Egypt Protests Go On, Seeking New Beginning
articles.snippet: In government ministries, factories and universities, protests have focused on those viewed as surrogates of Hosni Mubarak.
articles.abstract: In government ministries, factories and universities, protests have focused on those viewed as surrogates of Hosni Mubarak.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Banners fluttering from the rooftop of Cairo University’s faculty of mass communications denounce the dean as a Mubarak-era lackey. Fistfights between the dean’s student opponents and supporters erupt like summer squalls, with the din often emptying classrooms as students pour into the main lobby either to join the fray or watch.

articles.headline: Government Shutdown Would Have Wide Ripples
articles.snippet: The government is a very big business, and temporarily pulling the plug would disrupt many other businesses.
articles.abstract: The government is a very big business, and temporarily pulling the plug would disrupt many other businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s not just an estimated 800,000 federal employees who would feel the financial pinch of a government shutdown.

articles.headline: A Niche in the Wreckage of Florida Real Estate
articles.snippet: Investors are buying empty, dank properties cheaply and sprucing them up in hopes of selling them at a profit.
articles.abstract: Investors are buying empty, dank properties cheaply and sprucing them up in hopes of selling them at a profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH PORT, Fla. — One recent morning, Shannon Moore raced through a musty pink house — three bedrooms, two baths — that was advertised as having “good bones” and “primed for renovation.” As in many recently foreclosed homes in Florida, the appliances and air-conditioner were missing from this one, either taken by the previous residents or stolen.

articles.headline: Businesses Stand to Gain Most in Rivalry of States
articles.snippet: As states stage raids to entice companies to move, business leaders say the efforts only help companies at taxpayer expense.
articles.abstract: As states stage raids to entice companies to move, business leaders say the efforts only help companies at taxpayer expense.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — This city, sharing a name with one state but settled in another, has a long history of ugly border skirmishes dating back to the Civil War. And even today, the annual football showdown here between the University of Kansas and the University of Missouri is referred to as “The Border War.”

articles.headline: Disney Plans Lavish Park in Shanghai
articles.snippet: The company hopes to open the park by 2015 and to avoid the cultural mistakes that marred other park openings.
articles.abstract: The company hopes to open the park by 2015 and to avoid the cultural mistakes that marred other park openings.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The Walt Disney Company placed a huge bet on China’s shifting approach to Westernized entertainment on Friday as it broke ground here on a $4.4 billion theme park and resort — even if it is one without classic American features like a Main Street.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: No Accord in Budget Talks as Policy Fights Hamper Deal
articles.snippet: President Obama and Congressional leaders met to resolve an impasse that has shifted from budget cuts to disputes over issues like abortion and the E.P.A.
articles.abstract: President Obama and Congressional leaders met to resolve an impasse that has shifted from budget cuts to disputes over issues like abortion and the E.P.A.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Another day of intense negotiations between the two parties failed to yield a budget deal on Thursday, leaving the federal government hours from a shutdown.

articles.headline: Budget Deal to Cut $38 Billion Averts Shutdown
articles.snippet: Lawmakers reached a tentative deal shortly before a deadline that would have shuttered federal facilities and furloughed thousands of workers.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers reached a tentative deal shortly before a deadline that would have shuttered federal facilities and furloughed thousands of workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders and President Obama headed off a shutdown of the government with less than two hours to spare Friday night under a tentative budget deal that would cut $38 billion from federal spending this year.
